poem:
**Watershed**

In the ripples of discontent,
a levy rises unseen,
each drop, a small rebellion,
pooling in kitchen sinks,
bathtubs, and rain barrels.
Boycott Thames Water, 
the headline whispers,
as hands turn off taps,
and silence fills the pipes
with the quiet pulse
of public ownership,
the river longing to be free.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Here’s how we can fight back on water bills | Letter Public fury at the water industry can be channelled to achieve lasting change (Letters, 14 July). There are parallels with the revolt that brought down the poll tax. Our campaign – Boycott Thames Water – seeks to overturn the false narrative that taking water back into public ownership is unaffordable. If the Ofwat proposals pass, a water levy will be imposed on every household". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
